property.name: Flaked Stone Artefact Raw material type
property.description: Select the raw material type
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Basalt} Fine grained igneous rock, very common, often dark in colour, no other mineral inclusions, and sometimes with caviities

{Chalcedony} Hard, fine grained material composed of very small silica crystals, highly variable in colour. Unlike chert, chalcedony has a fibrous structure with fine intergrowths of quartz and often has a waxy lustre and is often semi-transparent or translucent
{Chert} Hard, fine grained material composed of very small silica crystals, highly variable in colour, and unlike chalcedony, lacks transparent or transluscent qualities
{Ironstone} Sedimentary rock, with substantial proportion of iron creating a reddish appearance on outer surface but internally is typically grey. Very hard material with poor flaking properties
{Mudstone} Very fine grained and at times quite soft sedimentary rock encompassing mudstone, siltstone and claystone. Not prone to lamination
{Quartz__clear} Clear, colourless and transparent or translucent material composed of silica
{Quartz__milky} White or milky-coloured material composed of silica, but lacks transparency of clear quartz

{Quartzite} Hard, non-foliated rock derived from quartz sandstone and metamorphosed, varying in colour depending on presence of other minerals, but typically white, grey, pink or red due to iron oxides. Quartz grains are cemented together to such an extent that fractures break through grain boundaries, rather than around them. Grainy or glassy appearance, but often excellent flaking properties
{Sandstone} A clastic sedimentary rock, typically of sand-sized mineral particles or rock fragments, often quartz and feldspar
{Shale} Very fine grained sedimentary rock, but unlike mudstones, is prone to lamination

{Silcrete__general} Hard, resistant material that can appear simiilar to quartzite but results from the dissolution of silica and its resolidification as a cement, along with other detrital materials. As a result, silcrete has a highly variable grain size but grains are usually evident and, unlike quartzite, fractures will break around grain boundaries. If confident in classification, please select specific silcrete type
{Silcrete_microcrystalline} Silcrete, very fine grained with almost no visible grains, and scattered quartz clasts

{Silcrete_medium_grained} Silcrete, mostly medium-sand-sized quartz clasts (0.25-0.5 mm) in a siliceous matrix, with sand grains easily visible. Coarser silcrete varieties tend to have poor flaking qualities, so consider whether this material is quarztite

property.name: Flake completeness
property.description: Assess the degree of flake fragmentation
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Complete} Ventral surface, platform, lateral margins and termination are preserved
{Proximal} Broken flake, termination absent with evidence of initation present (e.g. platform, bulb of percussion, bulbar scar or fissures)
{Medial} Broken flake, both proximal and distal margins absent (ie. termination and initiation points)
{Distal} Distal fragment, termination preserved but proximal margin absent (e.g. missing platform)
{Angular_fragment} Other fragment, typically amorphous with no characteristics of flakes, cores or tools

property.name: Platform surface
property.description: Select the type of platform present
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Absent} Select this if the platform is absent (e.g. medial flakes)
{Natural} An unmodified natural surface, typically with cortex, though not exclusively
{Flaked} A platform surface that has been flaked prior to removal of the flake being analysed
{Abraded} A platform surface that has been ground against a harder surface

property.name: Platform angle
property.description: Measure the angle between the platform and dorsal surface. Ideally, this should be recorded with a goniometer
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

property.name: Flaked Stone Artefact Platform width mm
property.description: Maximum width across the platform surface, and between the two lateral margins. Leave blank if either lateral margin is absent
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

property.name: Platform thickness mm
property.description: Maximum thickness of the platform, between the ventral and dorsal surface, and measured through the umbo and in line with the percussion axis . Leave blank if platform margin is only partially present (e.g. a crushed platform)
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

property.name: Maximum length mm
property.description: Length of percussion axis, or the length from the point of percussion to the most distal point. This becomes the maximum length on broken flakes where the platform or termination are absent
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

property.name: Maximum width mm
property.description: Maximum width, measured across the longest line that can be drawn at right angles to the percussion axis
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

property.name: Maximum thickness mm
property.description: Maximum thickness of flake, measured on and through the percussion axis
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

property.name: Termination type
property.description: The shape of the distal end of the flake or distal fragment
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Feather} Minimal thickness at the distal end, and a very acute angle bewteen the dorsal and ventral surface
{Axial} When the crack forming the termination moves through the core at an approximate right angle
{Hinge} The fracture meets the core surface at an approximate right angle to the percussion axis of the flake, less abrupt than a step fracture, typically bending from the ventral to dorsal surface
{Step} Flake is abruptly terminated with a right angled break, creating a distinctive step feature
{Plunging} The fracture plane curves markedly away from the core and then back into the core, typically leaving a J shaped termination that bends from the dorsal

property.name: Overhang removal
property.description: Indicate whether there is evidence of overhang removal, typically indicated by the scars on the dorsal surface of the flake that were created before it was detached, through platform preparation
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Ventral} Unifacial retouch initiated on the ventral surface, resulting in small flakes detaching from the dorsal surface
{Dorsal} Unifacial retouch initiated on the dorsal surface, resulting in small flakes detaching from the ventral surface
{Bifacial} Bifacial retouch, initiated on both dorsal and ventral surface

{Straight} In plan view, the retouched margin in mostly straight
{Irregular} In plan view, the retouched margin features a combination of edge-shapes

property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Core} Any core type, from which flakes have been detached
{Anvil} A stone used as a base on which other materials can be hammered or pounded, for example, bipolar flake production, or for cracking seeds
{Hammerstone} A stone used to detach flakes from a core, with evidence of pitting created through impact
{Muller} The top stone used in conjunction with a grindstone, which is used to grind seeds, ochre, or other materials
{Grindstone} The base stone or slab used in conjunction with a muller to grind seeds, ochre, or other materials
{Edgeground} An edge-ground implement, featuring a distinctive modified distal margin, used for chopping or cutting tasks

{Manuport} A stone within an archaeological assemblage or landscape setting where such stone does not occur naturally, and thus, must have been moved by humans. If this shows evidence of utilisation, select another category
{Pounder} An implement used to crack or crush other materials, typically vegetable materials. Can be difficult to distinguish from hammerstones
{Ochre} Soft, clay-earth pigment composed of ferric oxide, clay and sand, ranging from deep orange to brown in colour
{Multifunction} A stone used for at least two purposes (e.g. a core utilised for pounding). Complete all relevant fields below
{Other} Other stone materials utilised by people (e.g hearth stones)

property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Amorphous} Core shape does not conform to categories below
{Bipolar} A core with flakes typically struck from a platform, while the opposite surface is held against an anvil, creating impact damage (e.g. crushing) on the distal surface
{Horsehoof} Discoidal, high-domed core with step and hinge fractures along a single, circular or ovate, platform
{Microblade} Parallel elongate flake scars, each 2x longer than width, on a typically very small core (<10cm). Used to produce bladelets as a component for geometric microliths and backed blades
{Burin_blade_core} Produced from a flake that is similar in form to a burin, but with bladelets removed from the proximal end

property.name: Remaining cortical surface
property.description: Estimate the proportion of cortical surface remaining on the artefact
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

property.name: Usewear
property.description: Record any evidence of impact damage observed on the artefact
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Pitting} Small irregular indentations or pits (<5 mm) over a focal area, for example, the distal surface of a hammer stone
{Crushing} More invasive than pitting, characterised by small fragments of stone being crushed and falling away. Often leaves large pits

{Grinding} A raw material with at least one surface that is smoother than surrounding cortical surface, typically created by rubbing, and usually indicated also be a colour difference compared with cortex. Does not produce a visible groove
{Grooves} A distinct, concave and often elongate surface created by removal of raw material through abrasion (e.g. a broad groove on a grindstone)
{Waist} A narrow, ground or abraded band around the body of a tool (e.g. wasted stone axe)

property.name: Flaws
property.description: Detail the presence of any observable manufacturing flaws, such as poorly applied transfer prints, trivet/stilt marks, pinholes in the glaze, grit from the kiln adhered to the surface. This is really only applicable to domestic ceramics (teawares and tablewares). Note that this does not include marks made through use (e.g. scratches or removal of overglaze decoration).
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Poorly_applied_Transfer_print} Mismatched pattern edges, unevenly applied prints, missing sections of prints
{Pinholes} Evident in the glaze where small air bubbles have popped
{Trivet_stilt_marks} On the underside of vessels, caused by the separators between stacked items in the kiln adhering to the glaze
{Grit} Any grit or other inclusions adhered to the surface during firing

property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Open} An open fire, built directly on ground surface, not demarcated with stones, and lacking heat retainers
{Bounded} An open fire, built directly on ground surface, but with stones or other materials placed around edge of hearth
{Pit} A fire built in a pit, but lacking evidence of the use of heat retainers
{Earth_oven} A fire built in a pit, with heat retainers evident indicating its use as an earth oven
{Enclosed} A fire built in an enclosed setting, for example, within a brick, stone or metal enclosure

property.name: Heating element types

lookup.term: {Rare} Heating elements are distributed across less than 30% of the feature
{Moderate} Heating elements are distributed across 30â70% of the feature
{Frequent} Heating elements are distributed across more than 70% of the feature

lookup.term: {Complete} Ventral surface, platform, lateral margins and termination are preserved
{Proximal} Broken flake, termination absent with evidence of initation present (e.g. platform, bulb of percussion, bulbar scar or fissures)
{Medial} Broken flake, both proximal and distal margins absent (ie. termination and initiation points)
{Distal} Distal fragment, termination preserved but proximal margin absent (e.g. missing platform)
{Angular_fragment} Other fragment, typically amorphous with no characteristics of flakes, cores or tools

property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Indeterminate} Core fragment with flake initiation unclear
{Unidirectional_core} Flake scars originate from a single platform, and all flakes struck in the same direction
{Bidirectional_core} A core with two platforms, opposite each other, with flakes struck from each platform, and thus from opposite directions
{Bifacial_core} Single platform core, but flakes struck from two core faces
{Multidirectional_core} Two or more platforms, with no clear pattern in platform or scar orientation

property.name: Original base diameter
property.description: Estimate or measure the base diameter, where possible. Use certainly slider if appropriate)
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Cortical_platform} Striking platform is âcortexâ at point of force application. Cortex here refers to the original inner and outer surface of the bottle (after Gorman, 2000, p. 261).
{Single_facet_platform} Point of force application (PFA) is located on a flake scar or broken face.
{Dihedral} PFA is located on the ridge between two scars.
{Multifaceted_platform} PFA is located on a surface with multiple scars.
{Edge_platform} Flake initiated at the very edge of the platform. A discrete platform surface is not identifiable on the flake, but a clear PFA is present.
{Collapsed_crushed_platform} The platform shattered during impact. Platform dimensions cannot be recorded.

property.name: Distal termination
property.formatString: {{if $1 then $1}}{{if and($1, $2) then " " }}{{if $2 then $2}}{{if $3 then " ($3)"}}{{if between($4,0,0.49) then "??" elsif lessThan($4,1) then "?" }}

lookup.term: {Feather} Minimal thickness at the distal end, and a very acute angle bewteen the dorsal and ventral surface
{Axial} When the crack forming the termination moves through the core at an approximate right angle because the flake travelled through to the base of the core

{Hinge} Generally rounded termination. The fracture meets the core surface at an approximate right angle to the percussion axis of the flake, less abrupt than a step fracture, typically bending from the ventral to dorsal surface
{Step} Flake is abruptly terminated with a right angled break, creating a distinctive step feature
{Plunging} The fracture plane curves markedly away from the core and then back into the core, typically leaving a J shaped termination that bends from the dorsal
